newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila call loan rate rises for the third day.
newsitem.headline: Manila call loan rate rises for the third day.

text.p: The Philippine call loan rate rose for the third straight session on Wednesday to 11.96875 percent from 11.84375 as liquidity tightened, traders said.
"Rates in the interbank market continued to rise despite the cut in Central Bank overnight rates as most funds of major banks were invested in fixed-income securities," one trader said.
Early on Wednesday, the Central Bank cut its overnight borrowing rate to 10.5 percent from 10.75 while its lending rate dropped to 13 percent from 13.25.
Done rates ranged from 12.03125 percent to 11.0. Volume increased to 28.215 billion pesos from 22.244 billion.
There were 29 borrowers, including major banks, and 36 lenders.
Trading in government securities was dull, traders said.
"There were a lot of sellers but there were no takers," said one dealer.
Three-month bills were quoted at 12 percent, six-month bills at 12.4 percent, and one-year bills at 13 percent.
